author: Allan Seccombe
title: Implats CEO praised for shunning rewards | Mining
text:
Impala Platinum CEO Terence Goodlace says the R4bn it aims to raise will be used to complete new low-cost shafts at its two new mines. Picture: MARTIN RHODES Related articles Safety stoppage costs bite miners Implats plans to cut 1,500 jobs in Rustenburg Implats to raise R4bn to bolster its balance sheet In this article JSE-listed companies: Impala Platinum Holdings IMP View company tearsheet KHOTSO Mokhele, the departing chairman of Impala Platinum (Implats), said on Wednesday the company had to convince some shareholders it was not a bad thing for CEO Terence Goodlace to shun performance rewards, arguing his interests were aligned to theirs.
Mr Mokhele, who has been on the Implats board since 2004, has stepped down and will focus on his advisory role to the science and technology minister as well as his nonexecutive directorships at Tiger Brands, Zimplats, Hans Merensky Holdings and African Oxygen.
In a rather pointed comment in his farewell comments at Wednesday’s Implats annual general shareholders meeting, he said Mr Goodlace had the board’s full confidence despite some shareholders questioning his rejection of incentive schemes.
"His commitment to shareholder value and the rest of the stakeholders and business perhaps gets placed in doubt by this, but the board has no such worries because it sees how committed and dedicated he is to this company," Mr Mokhele said.
In its latest annual report, Implats said since joining the company in 2012, Mr Goodlace had steadfastly declined any increase in wages and participation in short-term or long-term incentive schemes.
"He remains resolute in his decisions based on low PGM (platinum group metals) basket prices and the financial crisis facing the platinum industry," it said, adding that his after-tax pay was R3.6m this year.
When compared to the lowest paid worker in the company it gave a ratio of 1:37, down from 1:41 last year, meaning Mr Goodlace earned the equivalent of 37 underground workers.
Mr Mokhele is setting up a trust to invest and encourage maths and science education in and around Bloemfontein, his home town, which he visits regularly. He is struck by the "vacuous stares" he sees and the sense of "utter hopelessness" he experiences there.
He is alarmed by the approach of the "nouveau riche noire", the newly wealthy black segment of society, which seeks short cuts to success rather than using education and hard work.
"You are screwed if you’re not with the ‘in group’. If you are with them then you’ll be screwed tomorrow when there’s a new ‘in group’. It’s this political dynamic of trying to be with the ‘in group’ to thrive that’s so concerning".
